captions.text:
My name is Christian
von Koenigsegg.

I'm 40 years old, and for half
of my life, I've been on the

quest to be a leader in the
hybrid car industry, utilizing

Swedish design combined with
visionary technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangars of

a former Swedish fighter
jet squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
probably painted on the back
of every Koenigsegg.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So the interior of the car
is as important as
anything else we do.

We spend a lot of energy and
time optimizing and making it

really special and unique, and
functional, of course.

I mean, this is the place where
the driver/owner and the

passenger spend most of his
time, so it's important that

you feel really special
inside the car and
that it works well.

So I'm going to tell you a
little bit about our ghost

lighting system that we
developed for the Agera.

Basically, we wanted something
elegant, clear, unique, and

ergonomic and nice for the
driver and the occupant to be

able to control the car and
its function in the best
possible way.

We thought it would be pretty
cool if we could have a metal

bottom, an aluminum bottom,
which is just as smooth and

nice, and you don't see or feel
anything until the light

turns on, and then it shows
up what it actually is.

And we had to spend a lot of
time to get the lighting

correct, to have it shiny enough
on the inside, to have

the surface thin enough so that
the light can penetrate

through the very small
etched laser holes.

And the holes were optimized in
size so that they're hardly

visible when the light is off,
but very visible when the
light is on.

Also, we have a philosophy
that inside the car,

basically, the only materials
you can touch is either

leather, carbon fiber,
or metal.
There's no plastic anywhere.

Here is the circuit board going
behind, and we actually

have a light in here, but also
four small LEDs, very strong
LEDs, inside each button.

You see this one is naked, so
this one goes like this and

moves together with
the button.

Then they're all spring mounted
on this very unique

circular spring, which
was developed.

We used a special spring steel
with a certain thickness and a

certain shape to get the right
spring effect going to have a

really nice click
for each button.

So we mimic the same
kind of features on
the steering wheel.

First of all, of course, it
has to be manufactured in

carbon fiber, baked
in the autoclave.

Then it has to be clear coated
in the paint shop.

Then we put the foam agent
underneath the leather, and
then the leather.

And that's about a one-day
process just
to apply the leather.

And then we have to fit all
the electronics, and the

paddle shifters, and circuit
boards, and make it
into what it is.

So the steering wheel is a
one-piece hollow carbon fiber

that we designed here, and it's
very optimized to the
interior of the car.

It's a little bit thinner up
top, so it's easier to see the
instrumentation.

It's got a flat bottom to make
it easier to get in and out of

the car, and it's got an
optimized grip section.

Also, underneath the leather,
there's a foam agent to make

the steering wheel more
compliant and to take out some

high-frequency vibration
that it's not--

well, that dilutes the input
from the road, basically.

Here we have also ghost
lighted buttons.

As you can see, they're just
shiny aluminum until
the light comes on.

And this goes into the steering
wheel here, one on

the left side and one
on the right side.

And there's a lot of
functionality and processing

going on in the steering
wheel, so we actually

developed a circuit board for
the steering wheel, which has

CAN bus communication and CAN
bus protocol going through
just a small amount of cables.

The reason why we have CAN bus
in the steering wheel is to

reduce the amount of cables
that has to go through the

axle and that has to spin
around all the time when
you're turning.

But it also gives us flexibility
to have different
functions for the buttons.

We can change symbols and change
software, and then we

have completely different
function
without rerouting cables.

Another thing which is very
important is that we have

these shifters mounted to
the steering wheel.

And we spent a lot of time
making sure we have the right

click feel, so it's like
a trigger, basically.
It's either on or off.
You can't press it halfway.

And it's also important that it
has a solid mounting base.

If you want to press it by the
tip, it doesn't flex at all.

And they're very long for being
steering wheel mounted.

So you get very good ergonomics
when you're turning
the steering wheel.

But most important
is how they feel.

They have a really nice trigger
feel click to them.

So there are several different
spring elements inside the

shifter to have the
right feel.

All in all, it's a very unique
product, the steering wheel
with all its functions.

And I would say normally it
would take almost the size of

our company just to develop a
thing like a steering wheel,

but that's something we
just do on the side.

And of course, the final part
is the airbag that goes in.

So it's a quite complex product,
the steering wheel
alone by itself.
Here we have an aluminum part.

All the aluminum parts inside
the car are machined from
billet aluminum.

And you can see here on the
backside there are some traces
of machining.

On the front side, of course,
the machining time is much

longer and slower to make
it really smooth.

After it's machined, it's
polished in a special
polishing machine.
It's not just tumbled.

It's a proprietary polishing
system, which makes it
extremely smooth.

And after that, it's anodized
to get a good surface
protection.

And this is the process that all
the aluminum parts in the
interior go through.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Feels Like a Million Bucks - /Inside Koenigsegg

comments.text:
+John Smith I just wanted to clear the air, I am just a big car fan I like 
them all, I don't side with a specific American brand, though Ford has been 
pretty reliable lately, I love the Challenger, and I think the new Stingray 
is one sexy piece of car, and I would definitely love to have an M4, but I 
ain't got the cash. And I've always been a car guy, but bikes are 
definitely pretty exciting, I want to get into the 2 wheel world just to 
experience it, so I'm thinking the first bike I wanna get is that Harley 
Iron 883, I don't know much about bikes but that thing looks pretty sexy 
and looks like a good beginner bike.
comments.author: Laika Buzz

comments.text:
+Laika Buzz

Dont misunderstand me, I would drive a corvette in a heartbeat. Its a car 
marketed at a different kind of person, and would be great fun to drive.

Having said that, expensive top end machinery will always win out due to 
the investment results.

For me, two wheels provide an even greater price per bhp ration that i 
prefer, if a corvette is a cessna then a GSXR is an ultralight.

With a jet engine ;)
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+John Smith Nope, I own a 2014 GT Mustang, a 2010 GMC SLT Sierra and before 
that a 2006 V6 Charger. You can't compare a hyper car that is purpose built 
like a master piece of art to a great attainable car that is fun to drive. 
You can't expect a Corvette that cost 60k to have the same type of 
craftsmanship as this insanely fast piece of art. The Koenigseng is a 
highly methodically artfully crafted automobile, the Corvette is a very 
well Engineered machine that does what its supposed to and it does it well. 
I could never afford this beauty, but I can definitely get my hands on a 
Stingray. Different leagues buddy, cant compare the 2. Industrial vs. 
Boutique.
comments.author: Laika Buzz

comments.text:
You can never appreciate the beauty of these cars until you try and build 
one yourself. Most people could not even build a wood dash for their car 
much less carbon fiber engine parts and that is what makes these cars stand 
out above any mass produced super car. But unless you see this car in 
person then you can never really appreciate it. I had a chance to sit in 
one and I said no as these cars seem so much of a piece of unattainable art 
that I felt that I might scratch it. These are some amazing cars and its 
really special how much pride these people invest into making one. Do 
something you love to do and you will never work a day in your life.﻿

comments.text:
I can really appreciate the thought and care that goes even into the 
steering wheel.  A day to build a wheel...I think GM builds an entire car 
in a day, which is sad.  As for the inevitable comparisons to Paganis, I 
think the visual simplicity of the Koenigsegg design defines its elegance 
and efficiency; function and form equally served. Those paddle shifters; I 
can just imagine how nice it feels to click those things, and listen to 
that solid, quality sound.  Much nicer than my $40 xbox 360 racing wheel :)﻿

comments.text:
+KidWeazel Didn't read the earlier prints it would seem. Thanks for 
correcting me! None the less, Spyker went under in 1929, and was restarted 
in 1999, seven years after pagani was founded. If you look at the old 
spykers there are no resemblances to pagani's interiors. As such, my point 
still stands.

I can also add, as someone who's been in a CCX and a CCR (which didn't even 
have the same quality as the agera) that the interior feels very expensive. 
I basically hopped over from the CCX into an SLR, and I can tell you that 
THAT was like stepping into a children's toy.

I apologize for saying "Apparently you don't know much about Pagani" in my 
last reply. I agree, if Pagani produced their own engines I would respect

comments.author: Marcus Thilen

comments.text:
+Marcus Thilen On this topic, its okey to say that Pagani is like a Venom 
GT.. i exaggerate but the fact remain, Pagani is not on the same level as 
Koenigsegg due to their lack of ambition to create something original. Its 
not a competition and people love Pagani, i love Pagani! But Horacio is not 
on par with Christian on this topic, in my opinion, due to lack of ambition 
to make the engine a part of Pagani.. K'egg was there aswell, a small 
unknown company with a Ford engine but did something about it.. they still 
use Michelin tires and i dont see a change anytime soon.. but if Horacio 
does that mile before Christian.. then he deserve extra credit from me!
comments.author: Denstoradiskmaskinen

comments.text:
+Denstoradiskmaskinen Pagani is a small company. When they were founded 
they did not have the capital to build engines so they bought mercedes 
engines and people loved the cars. Why fix what's not broken? (especially 
if it will cost you millions in R&D) They also build all their suspension 
components and aerodynamics. Look at the Huayra, it's a marvel of modern 
engineering, not because of it's engine but because of its aerodynamics. 
And they don't "buy pieces here and there..." all their aluminum is milled 
in house and their carbon fibre is woven in house as well. Apparently you 
don't know much about Pagani.
comments.author: Marcus Thilen

comments.text:
+sykesdenali2 Everything you said in this sentence is so wrong. Some 
corvettes are supercharged. Secondly its quite a common mistake to think 
Volskwagen actually makes/ does any part of the cars, but they dont. 
Lamborghini makes them from scratch. This car is computerized. Everything 
about this car is pure technological, in the meanwhile, The Aventador´s V12 
is hand built. And the new Corvette takes 3.8 seconds to 60. The Aventador 
takes 2.9. And im not even gonna talk about top speed.
comments.author: Nieves

comments.text:
+Chris Pappas Exactly! The Aventador, for instance is all drive by wire 
computer limited garbage. I'm a purist. I don't want manumatic shifters or 
turbos. I want an all motor powerplant with 100% of controls left with the 
driver. I'm also not interested in anything built by Volkswagen that's 
called fast, yet is beaten by factory Corvettes.

comments.text:
About that Ghost Lighting, what happens to the lighting when the tiny 
laser-drilled holes in the aluminum get filled up with black fingerprint 
grease?﻿
comments.author: ShaniqaPikes

comments.text:
+mze1111
Everything you touch gets skin oil on it.  Things that get handled a lot 
accumulate a black greasy mixture of skin oil, dead skin cells, and dirt.  
Look at your keyboard or the bottom of your computer mouse or the steering 
wheel in your car.  It's gross, but it's a fact.  I am just wondering how 
the Ghost Lighting system deals with it.  Maybe the buttons are removable 
and can be put in an ultrasonic jewelery cleaning bath or soaked in dish 
soap or something?
comments.author: ShaniqaPikes
